quizlist.question: Banks pay interest on which of the following?
quizlist.explanation: When you deposit some money in your account, your bank has the ability to use that money to make loans or investments. Essentially, you are lending money to your bank. Whenever one party loans money to another, it is customary for the lender to charge an interest rate. This is why the bank pays you interest on your deposits.

quizlist.question: Banks charge interest on which of the following?
quizlist.explanation: Whenever one party loans money to another, it is customary for the lender to charge an interest rate. A loan is nothing but lending of money, in this case, by the bank. Hence, banks have the right to charge you an interest on loans.

quizlist.question: Bank accounts are primarily classified into 4 types, those are:
quizlist.option1: Savings, Unified, Recurring Deposit, Repeating Deposit
quizlist.option2: Past, Current, Recurring Deposit, Fixed Deposit
quizlist.option3: Savings, Current, Recurring Deposit, Fixed Deposit
quizlist.option4: Savings, Investment, Recurring Deposit, Fixed Deposit
quizlist.explanation: Savings Accounts are meant for savings - as simple as that! These are generally used by salaried employees, retired professionals and even students. Current Accounts are mainly for business purposes. Such accounts allow for any number of transactions in a day. Recurring and Fixed Deposits can be used to gain attractive interests on deposits - in an RD, you deposit an amount every month but in an FD, it's a one-time deposit.

quizlist.question: What is a personal bank account?
quizlist.option1: It is a secret bank account, not meant to be disclosed
quizlist.option2: It is owned and operated by a single person
quizlist.explanation: Personal means one user - only one person depositing and withdrawing money and therefore security measures will be in place to make sure the right person is accessing the funds. Personal accounts are often kept completely separate from business and joint accounts because they are completely in the interest of one user rather than many.

quizlist.question: What is a joint bank account?
quizlist.option1: It is a combination of two or more personal bank accounts
quizlist.option2: It is owned and operated by two or more people
quizlist.explanation: Joint means two or more users - all of them having equal access to the depositing and withdrawal rights of the account. Joint accounts are especially common amongst spouses who wish to save together or manage expenses together.

quizlist.question: In Recurring Deposits or RDs,
quizlist.option1: A fixed sum is deposited every month
quizlist.option2: The period of deposit is a fixed tenure
quizlist.option3: The interest paid is mostly compound, hence attractive
quizlist.explanation: Recurring deposits, also known as RDs are term deposits which allow people to make regular deposits and earn attractive interests on them. Account holders can choose the period of the deposits and even the amount to be deposited regularly. The interest paid is compounded annually or depending on the scheme of the bank. At the end of the term, all of the money is returned to the RD account holder.

quizlist.question: In Fixed Deposits or FDs,
quizlist.option1: A fixed sum is deposited only once
quizlist.option2: The period of deposit is a fixed tenure
quizlist.option3: The interest paid is mostly compound, hence attractive
quizlist.explanation: Fixed deposits, also known as FDs are one-time deposits wherein a particular amount of money is deposited and the bank pays an attractive monthly interest on the same over a certain term which is generally longer than that of RDs. But again like RDs, the money, at the end of the term, along with all the interest is paid back to the FD account holder.

quizlist.question: Which type of deposits earns higher interest?
quizlist.explanation: Fixed deposits typically have their interest compounded, hence they naturally earn higher interest.

quizlist.question: ATMs can be used for
quizlist.option3: Obtaining a mini statement for your account
quizlist.explanation: ATMs are multi-purpose nowadays. They can, not only be used for cash withdrawals, but also to enquire regarding your account or to obtain a mini statement to track all your account transactions.

quizlist.question: ATM passwords should be
quizlist.option3: Shared with an employee from your bank
quizlist.explanation: ATM passwords, if compromised, can lead to hazardous consequences. And yes, it can be quite tempting to note it down someplace so that you don't have to take the effort to memorise it. But ATM passwords should never be noted down or shared with anyone. Better safe than sorry!

quizlist.question: How can you track your deposits, withdrawal amounts and interest payments?
quizlist.explanation: You can track all your transactions in the monthly statement for your account which is issued by your bank. If you have your bank account linked to the bank's online services (like a website or a mobile application) then you can use the same to track your transactions as well.

quizlist.question: A passbook for a bank account is
quizlist.option2: Contains all the transaction details of the account
quizlist.option3: Shows the current balance of the account
quizlist.explanation: A passbook is basically your bank account on paper. It shows all of the transactions that have happened in your account - withdrawals, deposits, interest payments, etc. It is a good habit to keep your passbook updated but nowadays, people prefer to get 'mini statements' of their account from an ATM or rather, operate their account entirely online.

quizlist.question: If you had a short-term goal which interest would be best typically?
quizlist.explanation: The real power of compound interest comes into picture only when the interest is compounded more frequently (such as daily or monthly) instead of over long intervals (yearly). And this is usually not the case - most compound interest schemes are offered over longer intervals. Hence, it is much desirable to opt for simple interest schemes for short term goals since then it wouldn't make much sense to have interest compounded then.

quizlist.question: When you use a debit card,
quizlist.option1: Your bank pays on your behalf, you will need to repay the bank later
quizlist.option2: The money gets directly debited from the account that your card is linked to
quizlist.option3: The money gets transferred to a certain 'debit' account
quizlist.explanation: When you use a debit card, the money comes directly out of your account which is the one linked to the card. The biggest advantage of a debit card? You're not borrowing money from your bank, which can keep you out of debt.

quizlist.question: When you use a credit card,
quizlist.option1: Your bank pays on your behalf, you will need to repay the bank later
quizlist.option2: The money gets directly debited from the account that your card is linked to
quizlist.option3: The money gets transferred to a certain 'credit' account
quizlist.explanation: A credit card allows you to borrow money from your bank to make purchases. You will have to repay the bank within a certain time period known as the 'grace period', otherwise you will have to pay a penalty - which is usually heavy! This is why, it is most advisable to pay all your credit card dues on time!

quizlist.question: Nomination can be done in
quizlist.explanation: Banks ask their account holders to make nominations which mean that they should nominate persons to whom the money lying in their accounts should go in the event of their death. Account holders can change the nomination any time. Nominations can be made for an SB, RD and even an FD account.

quizlist.question: Nomination, once done, can
quizlist.explanation: Nominations can be cancelled or they could be even changed - anytime!

quizlist.question: If there is a nominee to a bank account, then
quizlist.option1: The nominee is entitled to perform transactions on behalf of the account holder(s), even if they are alive
quizlist.option2: The nominee gets access to the account only when the account holder(s) cease to exist
quizlist.option3: The nominee gets access to the account when one of the bank employees allow them the same
quizlist.explanation: A nominee to an account (in this case, joint) will actually come into the picture, only and only when all of the account holders of the said account no longer exist. In the event of death of an account or locker holder, the bank can release the account proceeds or contents to the nominee without insisting upon a succession certificate, letter of administration or court order.

quizlist.question: The minimum age required to open a Savings Bank (SB) account in a bank, that can be completely operated by the account holder, is
quizlist.explanation: Most banks have two separate versions of accounts for minors - one for those below 10 years and another for those between the ages of 10 years and 18 years. When you open an account in the name of a child who has not yet turned 10, it has to be operated jointly with the parent or guardian. Whereas those opened for a minor between 10 years and 18 years of age can be operated by the child.

quizlist.question: The savings bank account that does not operate for more than 24 months is called
quizlist.explanation: If you have a current or a savings bank account and have not done any transactions through it for more than 12 months, then it will be classified as an inactive account. And if you don't do any transactions from a bank account for 24 months, then it will be classified as dormant or inoperative.

quizlist.question: The maximum amount that you may issue a cheque for is
quizlist.option3: Nothing - there is actually no limit
quizlist.explanation: There is no limit on the amount of money that you may write a check for - well, provided the funds are available in your account!

quizlist.question: The payment of a cheque can be stopped by which of the following?
quizlist.explanation: The beneficiary or the payee is the person to whom the payment is to be made, while the drawer of the cheque is the person who is issuing a cheque for a payment to be made from their own account to the beneficiary's. (Additionally, if you are the drawer, then your bank would be the drawee as it will be performing the transaction on your behalf) If required, the drawer can stop the payment of the cheque by alerting their bank to not perform the transaction.

quizlist.question: Crossed cheques can be encashed
quizlist.option1: At the cash counter of the bank
quizlist.option3: By depositing it in your bank account
quizlist.explanation: Once you cross a cheque and mention the payee name, the cheque can only be encashed by the payee by depositing the cheque in their bank account. However, the payee can also make further endorsements here. So instead of cashing it in their own account, they can endorse the cheque to someone else, who will then encash it by depositing it in their own account.

quizlist.question: Crossed cheques with 'A/c Payee' can be encashed
quizlist.option1: By only the Payee of the cheque
quizlist.option2: By the Payee as well as by those third parties to whom the Payee has endorsed the cheque to
quizlist.explanation: Account Payee or A/c Payee cheques can only and only be encashed by the Payee by depositing it in their bank account. The cheque cannot be further endorsed to others unlike crossed cheques.

quizlist.question: The interest on Savings Bank Deposits is paid
quizlist.explanation: Earlier, the interest on Savings Bank accounts was paid half-yearly. However, The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) reviewed this and asked banks to pay interest on a quarterly basis so that people are benefited from the same.

quizlist.question: Fixed Deposits
quizlist.option2: Are only returned to you after the maturity period
quizlist.option3: Can be withdrawn before maturity, but a penalty has to be paid
quizlist.explanation: FDs or Fixed Deposits operate for a certain tenure, known as the maturity period. After this maturity period gets completed, the money accumulated in your FD will be returned to you. But there are FDs with a 'premature withdrawal' option wherein, you can close your FD before its maturity period ends, but here is the catch - you will have to pay a penalty to the bank for the same.

quizlist.question: The interest on Fixed Deposits is compounded
quizlist.explanation: The interest on FDs is typically compounded quarterly. This is the reason why the overall interest obtained from an FD account is pretty good! (Though this is the general rule, the RD and FD interest rates might be different from bank-to-bank)

quizlist.question: The maximum tenure of Fixed Deposits is
quizlist.explanation: The minimum tenure for an FD is generally 7 days and the maximum  tenure is generally 120 months (10 years).

quizlist.question: If you put 200 rupees in a savings account that paid 5.5% simple interest each year, how much interest would you earn in five years?
quizlist.hint: Formula: Simple Interest (SI) = P*r*t, where P → Principal Amount, r → Rate of Interest per year in decimal and t → Time period in years
quizlist.explanation: We have the Principal Amount here as 200 rupees, the Rate of Interest in decimal would be 5.5/100 = 0.055 and the Time period has been given as 5 years. Hence, SI = P*r*t = 200*0.055*5 = 55 rupees.

quizlist.question: If you put 150 rupees in a savings account that paid 6% compounded yearly, how much money would you have earned in five years?
quizlist.hint: Formula: A = P(1+r/n)^(nt) , where A → Amount of money accumulated including the compound interest, P → Principal Amount, r → Rate of Interest per year in decimal, n → number of times the interest is compounded per year and  t → Time period in years
quizlist.explanation: We have the Principal Amount here as 150 rupees, the Rate of Interest in decimal would be 6/100 = 0.06 and the Time period has been given as 5 years. It is also mentioned that the interest is compounded yearly, hence n = 1 (once a year). Hence, A = P(1+r/n)^(nt) = 150(1+0.06/1)^(1*5) = 200.73 rupees.

quizlist.question: What does 'E or S' mean?
quizlist.explanation: Either or Survivor is the most common type of joint account and is applicable between any two individuals. Herein, either of them can operate the account and in the case of the death of one of the depositors, the other can continue or the final balance in the account along with all interests (as applicable at the time of closure) will be paid to the survivor.

quizlist.question: What does 'A or S' mean?
quizlist.explanation: Anyone or Survivor is a type of joint account and is normally held when more than two individuals start an account jointly. Here, any of the depositors can operate the account at a time and in case any of the depositors die, the others can continue the account and if required, the final balance along with interest will be paid to any of the survivor/s as requested.

quizlist.question: What does 'F or S' mean?
quizlist.explanation: Former or Survivor is a type of joint account applicable between any two individuals. Herein, only the first account holder can operate the account. The second depositor gets the right only on the death of the first after undergoing some basic formalities like submission of proof of death etc.

quizlist.question: What does 'L or S' mean?
quizlist.explanation: Later or Survivor is a type of joint account applicable between any two individuals. Herein, only the second account holder (latter) can operate the account. The survivor or the former account holder gets access to the fund only on death of the latter and on producing the proof for the same.

quizlist.question: An overdraft is
quizlist.option1: A piece of document that needs to be submitted to the bank at the time of opening a current account
quizlist.option2: An agreement made with a bank that allows a current account holder to withdraw more money than what they have in their account up to the approved limit
quizlist.option3: A money draft that has been overdue
quizlist.explanation: An overdraft facility works like an approved loan. Money can be withdrawn as and when required, even if the account does not hold that much, and an interest has to be paid only on the amount borrowed and only for time it was borrowed. This is most typically provided to Current Account holders.

quizlist.question: You will be asked for your PAN card or your Aadhar when
quizlist.option1: A certain deposit is less than 50,000 rupees
quizlist.option3: A certain deposit is equal to or greater than 50,000 rupees
quizlist.explanation: There is a limit on the amount of money you deposit in your savings bank account on a single day and it is restricted to 49,999 rupees if you don't provide your PAN details. If you're providing your PAN, then you can deposit any amount of money upto 1,000,000 rupees (10 lakh rupees). Very recently, this rule of providing PAN compulsorily was relaxed, now people can submit their Aadhar instead.

quizlist.question: While making nomination, the signature of the nominee is required on
quizlist.explanation: The signature of the nominee is actually not required during the nomination process. Instead it is required that the signatures of all the account holders are required, in case of joint accounts, during nomination.

quizlist.question: What is DBT or Direct Benefit Transfer scheme?
quizlist.option3: Transfer of subsidies or social benefits directly in the bank accounts of beneficiaries
quizlist.explanation: DBT (Direct Benefit Transfer) is a scheme launched by Government of India to transfer the benefits and subsidies of various social welfare schemes like LPG subsidy, old age pension, scholarships etc. directly in the bank account of the beneficiary.

quizlist.question: What is meant by Aadhaar seeding?
quizlist.option1: Duplicate issuance of Aadhaar, in case the original is misplaced
quizlist.option2: Linking of Aadhaar with the bank account
quizlist.option3: Transfer of Aadhaar from one person to another
quizlist.explanation: Aadhaar seeding is to link your Aadhaar to your bank account. This especially helps avail benefits from various government schemes that provide subsidies.

quizlist.question: What is a BSBDA?
quizlist.explanation: BSBDA or Basic Savings Bank Deposit Account is a type of ‘zero-balance’ account that does not require that the account holder maintain a minimum balance. You can have absolutely zero money in such accounts. These are primarily aimed towards enhancing financial inclusion among the economically weaker sections of the society.

quizlist.question: What kinds of services are available free in a BSBDA?
quizlist.option1: Receipt or credit of money through NEFT / RTGS
quizlist.option2: No annual maintenance charges on ATM-cum-Debit card
quizlist.option3: 4 withdrawals in a month (including ATM withdrawals)
quizlist.explanation: All of the mentioned are free services offered in a BSBDA - a free ATM-cum-Debit card with no annual maintenance fees, deposit and withdrawal services are free of cost, and so is the passbook facility. Also, the bank cannot levy charges for non-operation or activation of an inoperative BSBDA.

quizlist.question: NEFT or National Electronic Funds Transfer
quizlist.option1: Is a one-to-one money transfer method
quizlist.option2: Has a limit of 50,000 rupees per transfer but has no limit on the number of transfers per day
quizlist.option3: Can be performed using your net banking portal
quizlist.explanation: NEFT is one of the many methods of money transfer used nowadays. While the mentioned points stand true for NEFT, one important thing to be noted is that NEFT transfers are handled in batches on working days and hence is not available on Sundays and on bank holidays.

quizlist.question: RTGS or Real Time Gross Settlement
quizlist.option1: Has a minimum limit on the amount that can be transferred
quizlist.option2: Has a maximum limit on the amount that can be transferred
quizlist.explanation: RTGS is especially used by business owners and business professionals to transfer large amounts of money - there is a minimum limit of 2 lakh rupees for every transaction. In RTGS, unlike NEFT, the entire amount is transferred in real time (instead of batches) and hence it happens faster and is more dependable in case of emergencies.

quizlist.question: Using IMPS, one can
quizlist.option2: Transfer money even if they do not have a bank account
quizlist.explanation: IMPS or Immediate Payment Service combines the best of NEFT and RTGS. It is available 24/7 and can be operated even if you do not have a bank account. Those without a bank account can use a PPI. PPIs are Prepaid Payment Instruments, the most common example of which is a digital wallet. With IMPS, you can transfer smaller amounts instantly and hence this is the most widely used transfer method.

quizlist.question: To use UPI, you need to
quizlist.option1: Have a bank account in a UPI member bank
quizlist.option2: Have a UPI application on your mobile phone and link the application to your bank account (eg: BHIM or PayTM)
quizlist.option3: Have your mobile number registered with your bank.
quizlist.explanation: UPI or Unified Payment Interface is the most common and trendiest of money transfer methods out there! Apart from the prerequisites that we saw, it is required to create a 4-digit UPI pin on your UPI app and also provide details of your debit card. Unlike IMPS, you compulsorily need your bank account here, because that is what is linked to UPI for payments. For example, it is not PayTM that would be linked to UPI, it would be your bank account that would be linked to UPI, you would only need PayTM as a mobile app for facilitating the process.

quizlist.question: A financial year starts from and ends on
quizlist.explanation: While a calendar year, as everyone knows, starts from 1st January and ends on 31st December, a financial year, instead, starts from 1st April and ends on 31st March. Financial year is also known as previous year.

quizlist.question: Income tax is charged in
quizlist.explanation: Financial Year or FY (or Previous Year) is the year in which you earn your income. Assessment Year or AY is the year following the financial year in which you have to evaluate the previous year's income and pay taxes on it. Both of these start from 1st April of a year and end on 31st March of the next year. However, for example, if we talk about the period between 1st April 2019 and 31st March 2020, it would be FY 19-20 and so, the period between 1st April 2020 and 31st March 2021 would be AY 20-21 during which we would be paying tax for the income earned in FY 19-20.

quizlist.question: The year in which income is earned is known as
quizlist.explanation: Income is earned in the financial year or previous year. Both of these terms mean the same. Assessment Year is the year that immediately follows the financial year wherein you actually pay your taxes.

quizlist.question: Taxes are classified into two major types
quizlist.explanation: There are two major types of taxes: direct and indirect. The implementation of both of these differ - direct taxes are those which you pay directly - income tax, corporation tax, property tax, etc. and indirect taxes are those paid indirectly - sales tax, GST, etc.

quizlist.question: Which of the following is a direct tax?
quizlist.explanation: Income tax, corporation tax (or corporate tax) and wealth tax are direct taxes whereas, VAT, service tax, GST, excise duty, entertainment tax and customs duty are indirect taxes.

quizlist.question: Which of the following is an indirect tax?
quizlist.explanation: Income tax, corporation tax (or corporate tax) and wealth tax are direct taxes whereas, VAT, service tax, GST, excise duty, entertainment tax and customs duty are indirect taxes.

quizlist.question: Corporate tax is
quizlist.option1: To be paid by the companies registered under company law in India
quizlist.option2: Taxed on the income gained by a company
quizlist.explanation: Corporate tax in India is levied on both domestic as well as foreign companies. Like all individuals earning income are supposed to pay a tax on their income, business houses too are supposed to pay as tax a certain portion of their income earned. This tax is known as corporate tax, corporation tax or company tax. It is a direct tax.

quizlist.question: GST or Goods and Services Tax
quizlist.option2: Has replaced a majority of other indirect taxes that previously existed
quizlist.option3: Is levied on the supply of goods and services
quizlist.explanation: GST was introduced in the year 2017 and has replaced other indirect taxes such as excise duty, VAT, etc. It is applied to all the goods and services of the country.

quizlist.question: Professional Tax is
quizlist.option1: Levied by the State government on all individuals who earn a living through any medium
quizlist.option2: Different for different states and union territories of the country
quizlist.option3: Limited to about 2500 rupees per year
quizlist.explanation: Professional tax can be defined as a tax that is levied by a state government and needs to be paid by each and every individual earning income. The calculation of this tax and the amount collected differs from one state to another. However, the limit has been set to Rs. 2500 per year.

quizlist.question: What do you mean by 'tax liability'?
quizlist.option1: The time period within which you should pay your tax
quizlist.option2: The amount of money you owe to tax authorities as tax
quizlist.option3: The amount of money the government owes you after you pay tax
quizlist.explanation: Tax liability is the total amount of tax debt owed by an individual, corporation, or other entity to a taxing authority like the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). In other words, it is the total amount of tax you're responsible for paying to the taxman.

quizlist.question: What is a capital gain?
quizlist.option1: It is the rise in the taxes that you pay with each increasing year
quizlist.option2: It is the rise in the value of capital assets over time
quizlist.option3: It is the gain that the economy earns with increasing GDP
quizlist.explanation: Capital gain is a rise in the value of a capital asset (investment or real estate) that gives it a higher worth than the purchase price. The gain is not realized until the asset is sold. A capital gain may be short-term (one year or less) or long-term (more than one year). Capital gains have to be considered while calculating taxes.

quizlist.question: What are 'heads of income'?
quizlist.option1: The different sources of income that a person can earn income from
quizlist.option2: The heads of the 5 departments of Income Tax in the IT department
quizlist.option3: The designations applied to bank employees for tax duties
quizlist.explanation: As per the Income Tax Act, a person can earn income from different sources and these sources are categorised as heads of incomes. There are 5 heads of income, which are: salary, income from house property (rent), profit and gains from business or profession, capital gains, income from other sources (interest, lottery, etc.)

quizlist.question: What is Gross Total Income or GTI?
quizlist.option1: It is the sum of the income you earn by adding all heads of income
quizlist.option2: It is the income based on which your actual tax is calculated
quizlist.explanation: Gross Total Income or GTI is a total of all forms of incomes, including income from salary, property, business or profession, profits or gains, and other sources like interest, etc. There are certain deductions performed on the GTI and the resultant amount is the Total Income or TI which is used for tax calculation then.

quizlist.question: What do you mean by deductions?
quizlist.option1: The amount that is deducted from your Total Income as tax
quizlist.option2: The amount that is deducted from your Savings Bank account as tax
quizlist.option3: The amount that is deducted from your Gross Total Income to bring down your tax liability
quizlist.explanation: Deductions are amounts (such as investments) that reduce your Gross Income. These are the amounts that the Income Tax Department allows you to reduce your income, bringing down your tax liability. Deductions are allowed under section 80 of the Income Tax Act (Section 80C to 80U).

quizlist.question: Contrary to GTI, Total Income or TI is
quizlist.option1: It is the sum of the income you earn by adding all heads of income
quizlist.option2: It is the income based on which your actual tax is calculated
quizlist.explanation: Total Income is basically GTI minus deductions. Deductions could mean money used for investments such as a life insurance, health insurance, a PPF, etc. or money earned as royalty. Once all the relevant deductions are claimed, from the GTI, the amount left is the Total Income or TI which is used to calculate your tax.

quizlist.question: As of FY 2019-20, wealth tax
quizlist.option1: Is not paid because it was abolished
quizlist.option2: Is paid but not by everyone
quizlist.option3: Has been changed into an indirect tax
quizlist.explanation: Wealth tax was introduced upon the richer strata of society. The intention of doing so was to bring parity amongst the taxpayers. However, wealth tax was abolished in the budget of 2015 (effective FY 2015-16) as the cost incurred for recovering taxes was more than the benefit is derived.

quizlist.question: Which of the following taxes was abolished by the Goods and Services Tax or GST?
quizlist.explanation: GST replaced all central and state indirect taxes like CENVAT, excise, customs, VAT, state excise, etc.

quizlist.question: What does TDS mean?
quizlist.explanation: TDS or Tax Deducted at Source is income tax deducted from the money paid at the time of making specified payments such as professional fees, salary, interest etc. by the persons making such payments. Usually, the person receiving income is liable to pay income tax. But the government with the help of Tax Deducted at Source provisions makes sure that income tax is deducted in advance. Hence, in simple words, TDS is what your company will deduct from your salary as tax in advance before paying you. This TDS is what your company will pay the government on your behalf. Another example of TDS is banks deducting tax from the interest earned on your deposits (FDs, RDs).

quizlist.question: Which among the following is not a head of income?
quizlist.explanation: There are 5 heads of income, which are: salary, income from house property (rent), profit and gains from business or profession, capital gains, income from other sources (interest, lottery, etc). Hence, income from exports is not a head of income amongst the given options.

quizlist.question: If 'Tata Company' imports a product from abroad, then which tax will be levied on it?
quizlist.explanation: Custom duty is imposed on imported and exported goods.

quizlist.question: Which of the following taxes is imposed by the Central Government but the State government collects it instead?
quizlist.explanation: When people talk about purchasing real estate, they often talk about the amount of 'Stamp Duty' that they will need to pay. Stamp duty is tax paid to register a document, typically an agreement or transaction paper between two or more parties, with the registrar. It is not just limited to a property agreement, it extends to all kinds of agreements. While the right to impose stamp duty lies with the Central Government, the State government has the right to collect it.

quizlist.question: You sell your property after holding it for more than 3 years, what does that qualify as?
quizlist.explanation: An asset that is held for more than 36 months is a long-term capital asset. Tax has to be paid on capital gains, whether long term or short.

quizlist.question: You have some gold jewellery that you have been holding for a year now and want to sell off, what does that qualify as?
quizlist.explanation: An asset that is held for 36 months or lesser is a short-term capital asset. Tax has to be paid on capital gains, whether long term or short.

quizlist.question: Tax slabs or tax brackets are
quizlist.option1: The categories into which one’s income is classified as so as to decide their tax liability
quizlist.option2: The installments of one’s tax that they pay monthly
quizlist.option3: The categories of people who are excluded from paying taxes
quizlist.explanation: Tax slabs or tax brackets are blocks that decide one's tax liability. Your income decides what slab you fall under and consequently how much tax you are supposed to pay. Under the new tax regime for F.Y. 2020-21, the slabs decided are: upto 2.5 lakhs, 2.5 to 5 lakhs, 5 to 7 lakhs and so on. There are certain other slabs for senior and super senior citizens earning income as well.

quizlist.question: ITR or Income Tax Return is
quizlist.option1: A form in which taxpayers file information about their income earned and tax applicable to the IT department
quizlist.option2: A form which, once submitted, ensures that you will be returned all the taxes that you paid that year
quizlist.explanation: Income Tax Return (ITR) is a form in which taxpayers file information about their income earned and tax applicable to the IT department. Every taxpayer should file their ITR on or before the specified due date. There are 7 types of ITR forms, the applicability of which varies depending on the sources of income of the taxpayer, the amount of the income earned and the category the taxpayer belongs to.

quizlist.question: The return of income is to be furnished in
quizlist.option4: ITR 1 to 7 (as the case may be)
quizlist.explanation: Under the Income Tax law, different forms of return of income are prescribed for different classes of taxpayers. The return forms are known as ITR forms (Income Tax Return forms). Thus, the return of income is to be furnished in ITR 1 to 7 (as the case may be).

quizlist.question: On successful filing of ITR, which one of the following is returned to you as an acknowledgement?
quizlist.explanation: ITR - V (V for Verification)  is the acknowledgement form that is returned to the one who has successfully filed their ITR. It comes into picture if you file your ITR without a digital signature and hence to get your ITR verified by the department, you will need to send a physical and signed copy of the ITR - V form to the CPC office, Bangalore.

quizlist.question: Form 16 is
quizlist.option1: Proof that you have been paid your salary in full
quizlist.option2: Proof that your employer deducted TDS from your salary
quizlist.explanation: Form 16 is the certificate issued under the Income Tax Act for tax deducted at source (TDS) from income under the head 'salary'. It is issued on deduction of tax by the employer from an employee's salary and deposit of the same with the government.

quizlist.question: There is no need to file your income tax return if
quizlist.option1: TDS has been deducted and all taxes have been duly paid
quizlist.option2: Your employer allows you exemption from the same
quizlist.option3: Your taxable income is below the basic exemption of Rs. 2.5 lakh per year
quizlist.explanation: Even if all of your taxes are paid, you still have to file your tax return. Your employer cannot exempt you from the same either. Only if your total income is below the basic exemption limit of Rs. 2.5 lakh per year, you are exempt from filing your tax return.

quizlist.question: A boon that saves you from the wrath of taxes is
quizlist.explanation: Under Sections 80C and 80D of the Income Tax Act, there are deductions allowed that help reduce your taxable income and these are only available if you make some tax-saving investments. Such investments include pension schemes, insurance, equity, etc.

quizlist.question: Advance tax is
quizlist.option1: A part of your taxes that you pay in the financial year itself, so in advance
quizlist.option2: To be paid if your tax liability is more than 10,000 rupees for a financial year
quizlist.explanation: Advance tax refers to paying a part of your taxes before the end of the financial year. Also called 'pay-as-you-earn' scheme, advance tax is the income tax payable if your tax liability is more than Rs.10,000 in a financial year. By paying in advance, you help the government and also yourself by not finding it hard to pay the whole tax at one go at the end. This way, if your advance tax liability has exceeded Rs 10,000, you are expected to pay it in the same financial year.

quizlist.question: Advance tax is generally not paid by salaried employees as
quizlist.option1: Their company/firm pays it on their behalf
quizlist.option2: Their tax is already cut as TDS from their salary by their employer
quizlist.explanation: Advance tax is applicable to individuals who earn income from sources other than salary. In the case of salaried employees, their salary is subjected to TDS and hence they need not pay advance tax. However, if a salaried employee has sources of income other than their salary, which makes their tax liability more than 10,000 rupees in that financial year then yes, they will need to pay advance tax!

quizlist.question: If you find that you are yet to pay some taxes, even after taking TDS and advance tax into account, then
quizlist.option1: You will need to wait for the next assessment year for paying them
quizlist.option2: You can pay them in the same assessment year as 'self-assessment tax'
quizlist.option3: You will need to especially contact the Income Tax Department for this pending tax
quizlist.explanation: If you find that, even after paying your TDS and advance tax, you still have some taxes left to be paid (say, an FD that was left unaccounted for or your TDS wasn’t paid fully), you can pay them as ‘self-assessment tax’ or SAT. It can be done online using a simple net banking procedure or through your bank as well. However, do remember that SAT should be paid before filing your income tax returns for that year.

quizlist.question: Total tax is
quizlist.option2: The total of all your taxes - TDS, advance tax and self-assessment tax
quizlist.option3: The sum of all the taxes that the government earns per year
quizlist.explanation: Total tax is the tax that you pay on your entire income received from all sources and could be more than the tax deducted at source by your employer or other income sources. This means that TDS will not take care of your entire tax liability and you will have to pay this additional tax as self-assessment or advance tax before filing the returns.

quizlist.question: You can claim a deduction of Rs 1.5 lakh from your total income by
quizlist.option2: Investing in a 5-year FD bank account
quizlist.explanation: You can claim a deduction of Rs 1.5 lakh from your total income under Section 80C. In simple terms, you can reduce up to Rs 1,50,000 from your total taxable income by investing in various instruments like PPF (Public Provident Fund), NSC (National Saving Certificate), investing in an FD or Fixed Deposits account, etc.

quizlist.question: If Rs. 1.5 lakh limit under Section 80C has gotten exhausted, you can save more tax by
quizlist.option1: Investing in the National Pension Scheme (NPS)
quizlist.option2: Contributing to the Voluntary Provident Fund
quizlist.option3: Buying a pension plan from an insurance company
quizlist.explanation: Under Section 80CCD, a taxpayer can claim deduction for investment of up to Rs 50,000 in the NPS or National Pension Scheme. This deduction will be over and above the Rs 1.5 lakh under Section 80C.

quizlist.question: You didn’t submit proof of your tax-saving investments, so your employer cuts your tax. Now you can
quizlist.option1: No longer claim the deduction if it does not figure in your Form 16
quizlist.option2: Claim the deduction later but won’t be eligible for tax refund
quizlist.option3: Claim the deduction at the time of filing your return and get a refund
quizlist.explanation: A taxpayer can claim deduction at the time of filing their ITR even if it does not figure in their Form 16. They will be eligible to claim a refund of the excess tax paid. Though there is no need to submit proof at the time of filing ITR, the taxpayer may be asked to furnish it later.

quizlist.question: You have a Savings Bank (SB) account and are regularly earning interest from it, which of the following is possible in this scenario?
quizlist.option1: You can write to the bank manager to exempt you from certain taxes
quizlist.option2: You can convert the account from an SB type to an FD (Fixed Deposits) type to save on taxes under Section 80TR
quizlist.option3: You can claim deduction of up to Rs. 10,000 on your taxes via Section 80TTA
quizlist.explanation: Section 80TTA provides a deduction of Rs 10,000 on interest income earned from your savings account with a bank, co-operative society, or post office. For this, you need to include your interest under the head 'Income from Other Sources' in your ITR.

quizlist.question: You invested in FDs but no TDS was deducted. You should
quizlist.option1: Ignore reporting the income because the bank didn’t deduct TDS
quizlist.option2: Add the amount to your annual income and pay tax on it
quizlist.option3: Mention income in ITR but claim exemption for bank interest
quizlist.explanation: Income from fixed deposits is fully taxable and has to be mentioned as income from other sources. The taxpayer has to pay tax at the marginal rate applicable to them. The exemption under Section 80TTA is for interest earned on savings bank balance, not for interest from fixed deposits.

quizlist.question: The consolidated tax credit statement of all your taxes paid as well as any tax refunded is available in
quizlist.explanation: Form 16AS is an annual consolidated tax statement that can be accessed by all taxpayers using their Permanent Account Number (PAN) on the IT website. While Form 16 is a record of only the TDS deducted, Form 16AS consists of details of TDS, TCS (Tax Collected at Source), advance tax, self-assessment tax, etc.

quizlist.question: TDS was deducted on the interest from your tax-saving FDs. What now?
quizlist.option1: You will not have to report the income because the tax has already been paid
quizlist.option2: You will have to add the income to your annual income and pay additional tax if necessary
quizlist.option3: You can claim a refund of the TDS because these were tax-saving FDs
quizlist.explanation: Interest income is fully taxable at the rate applicable to the investor. TDS is only 10%. If the taxpayer is in a higher tax bracket, they will have to pay additional tax. This can’t be ignored because income and TDS details will figure in Form 26AS of the taxpayer and alert the tax authorities.

quizlist.question: Mrs. Joshi has an FD in her minor child, Diya's name that earned Rs 1,400. This income is
quizlist.option1: To be mentioned in the ITR by Mrs. Joshi
quizlist.option2: Eligible for tax exemption and need not be mentioned in the ITR
quizlist.explanation: Though the income of a minor child is to be clubbed with that of the parent, there is a small Rs 1,500 exemption per child. Income beyond Rs 1,500 will be clubbed with that of the parent and taxed at the marginal rate. One can claim this exemption for a maximum of two children.

quizlist.question: If you live in your parent's home, you can pay them rent, but
quizlist.option1: You can’t claim exemption of (HRA) house rent allowance against such payments
quizlist.option2: The rent received by your parent will be fully taxable
quizlist.option3: Your parent will have to pay tax on the rent after 30% standard deduction
quizlist.explanation: It is perfectly legal to pay rent to a parent and claim exemption for HRA. Only 70% of the rent received by the parent will be taxed as income. The rules are different in case of spouses. One cannot pay rent to a spouse and claim HRA exemption.

quizlist.question: Which of these can't be claimed as a deduction by individual taxpayers?
quizlist.option2: Health insurance of self and family
quizlist.option3: Preventive health check-ups of self and family
quizlist.explanation: Though accidental death and disability insurance is very important, the premium paid for this cover cannot be claimed as a deduction by an individual. However, a company can show the premium it pays for group accidental cover as a legitimate business expense.

quizlist.question: You are currently working at a firm but aspire to go for higher education abroad. You avail a loan for the same. Hence,
quizlist.option1: You can use the loan to claim deduction from taxes under Section 80E
quizlist.option2: You can choose to have the bank pay your taxes as you study
quizlist.explanation: A deduction is allowed to an individual for interest on loans taken for pursuing higher education under Section 80E. It is necessary that the loan be availed from a legitimate financial institution and not your employer in this case. This loan may have been taken for the taxpayer, spouse or children or for a student for whom the taxpayer is a legal guardian.

quizlist.question: Banks provide loans for which of the following?
quizlist.explanation: Banks and credit unions lend money in the form of loans for significant, but necessary items like a car, education (student loan) or home.

quizlist.question: Timely repayment of loans results in
quizlist.option3: Easy availability of loans in the future
quizlist.explanation: It is always a good habit to repay your loans on time. This results in banks and lenders getting an idea about your accountability and reliability. It also makes it easier for them to loan you money again in the future!

quizlist.question: A defaulter of loan means
quizlist.explanation: Not paying loan instalments in the specified duration of time makes you a loan defaulter - and you sure don’t want to be one!

quizlist.question: Banks do not give loans against
quizlist.explanation: The rest of them are actual investments or items that can be produced as assets. Lottery tickets are none of those!

quizlist.question: Education loans
quizlist.option2: Are repayable after completion of course
quizlist.option3: Granted for studies in India & abroad
quizlist.explanation: Education loans help provide for tuition fees and expenses required for pursuing studies in India and even overseas. An interesting fact about education loans that make them different from other types of loans - they can be repaid after the student has completed their course and secured a job.

quizlist.question: What does PPF mean?
quizlist.explanation: Public Provident Fund (PPF) scheme is a popular long term investment option backed by Government of India. When you open a PPF account, you are required to deposit a certain amount every month to it, for which the bank gives you an attractive interest. At the end of the specified time period, all that money is returned to you, hence think of it as an investment. What more - you can use your PPF account to gain tax exemption!
